column25: I was vegetarian (pescatarian) since the age of 13, but when I was around age 29 I wanted to improve my health and hormones. I started eating steak once a week to improve my iron levels, protein intake, and hormone health before trying to get pregnant. It was the thing that really helped me and now my health is so much better. I also occasionally consume bone broth products. However it's important to me that any meat produce I consume is organic and pasture raised.

column24: Yes, I have tried a vegan diet.
column25: I don't have a problem in eating meat if it is farmed correctly. I buy my meat from local friends who breed goats and sheep, I have a friend who looks after deer on a deer park, so I buy venison of row deer (roe deer produce twins and therefore culling to keep populations down is needed, especially amongst stags who fight in rutting season). I also keep half a dozen sheep that I breed, I keep the ewes and send the boys off in the spring as hogget. For me eating purely vegetables is bad for the environment, without animals to fertilise the land we have to use artificial fertiliser. I am totally against chemicals on the land and would prefer to pay more for meat as a luxury item and go back to traditional farming techniques that use field rotation.
column26: A change in land management, more organic, GM free fruit and veg

column21: Meat-reducer (reducing meat consumption or only eating it occasionally)
column24: I have tried both vegetarian and vegan diets.
column25: I have been on and off a vegetarian diet since childhood. Although I care deeply about animal welfare and would want to continue a vegetarian diet, I have an unhealthy relationship with food and body image and a restrictive diet has been difficult for my mental health. I tried a vegan diet and really enjoyed trying new things, but during COVID lockdowns it became very difficult to get dairy free products (or a lot of food really) so my diet was restricted to what food was available to purchase from my local store.
column26: Availability of vegetarian and vegan protein alternatives. I love vegetarian dishes, but I struggle to get enough protein and I don't want to have to rely on vegan protein powder. I love tofu, seitan etc but it's not as easily accessible as the 'junk' vegetarian food that I don't really care for (Quorn for example). When firm tofu is on the shelf at Lidl, I pick it up, but I don't want to have to go to a separate supermarket just to purchase vegetarian meat alternatives. (Usually Waitrose is the only place with healthy vegan proteins that aren't full of sugar)

column87: I would only ever feed a plant based diet if required based on health concerns. It is unfair to place my beliefs of animal welfare onto an animal that doesn't understand, and requires a balance of meat and vegetables for a healthy diet. High amounts of single source novel proteins are best for dogs, and it has been proven again and again. Over consumption of animal products is not in our dog's paws, it is up to the general public to make a change. The animal products that dogs generally eat are waste products of the meat industry anyway, and so my dog's diet is a non issue.

column25: I believe animals should be treated kindly and I care about their welfare-watching a video of animals getting slaughtered for meat in school really influenced my thoughts on this. Outside of that, I was not a big fan of the taste of meat as is and I knew it was better for the environment and for the lives of the animals overall, making me feel solid in my decision.
column26: I think it gets easier every day as more options become available, especially when going out for food. I hate vegetarian options that try to taste too much like real meat, so I think more consideration of that in available options would be great. I also think having more information actively around (e.g, recipes, info on the impact youâ€™re making, etc.) would help to have kept up my motivation when I started. I think lack of information on how a vegetarian diet should work to ensure health is what led to more slip ups when I was first trying to be vegetarian as a teen, especially as my family are not vegetarian.

column25: I was raised as a vegetarian until I turned 16 and was given the choice to eat meat. I decided I wanted to try meat and had a meat diet until my mid-twenties, when I started to reduce my meat consumption as I felt guilty about eating meat. I would have eliminated meat from my diet entirely, but my partner still eats meat, and as a compromise I continue to eat white meat, but have removed red meat from my diet.
column26: More choices and better quality vegetarian options in supermarkets would make it easier for me now to keep a vegetarian diet. Meat-free alternatives for burgers and sausages are getting better, but they are ultra-processed foods which mostly don't taste very nice.

column24: Yes, I have tried a vegetarian diet.
column25: I was a vegetarian for over a decade, including the whole of the 1990s. But I came to believe that it was anti-life. That our ancestors believed they took on the strength of the animals they hunted, and that there was something in this. I also wanted to try different meats and fishes from around the world. A vegetarian diet wasn't always healthy, there was plenty of potential to get addicted to junk such as chocolate and chips. I do care about cruelty to animals and my environment (last night I rescued a hedgehog from the middle of the road). I believe factory farming should be minimised and high quality meat should be prioritised. And obviously animals and fish should not be hunted to extinction. Or bred into hideous meat-producing freaks. Also, for example, sharks should not be hunted for their fins.
column26: It was definitely harder to be a vegetarian in the 1990s, but I also felt I was missing out on high-quality meals. I was befriended by a married couple who gave lavish dinner parties. They were tolerant of my vegetarianism, but I was tempted to try all the other dishes they were serving. For example, when they served oysters I wanted to try them. To my mind there isn't much difference between eating oysters and eating blackberries, they're not really sentient. However, I will rescue a hedgehog from the road because it's an endangered creature.

column25: Simply put it was the realisation that animal welfare was far more important than my own food desires.  I tried eating vegetarian about 30 years ago and found it hard to produce healthy, tasty and balanced meals but nowadays there are many good vegan and vegetarian products a person can buy.  My cooking knowledge and abilities are good and I enjoy producing a good vegetarian meal.
column26: It is much easier these days as there are many  vegetarian, although processed, foods available which are satisfying, tasty and healthy. I prefer to cook using fresh produce, organic and home grown at times but do use processed vegan abd vegetarian products too.  I feel much happier in not contributing to the cruelty side of animal farming which can be much improved from the factory style of meat production that is now rampant.

column24: Yes, I have tried a vegan diet.
column25: It was an initiative of my partner who cooks most of our meals. After a bit the diet caused him to become ill and he gave up on it. I didn't have any negative reaction to the same diet but found it a bit challenging, complicated to source all the ingredients and time-consuming toprepare, and often not that tasty.
column26: Because the diet made my partner ill, there was no way to continue. In retrospect we should have taken advantage of a service that delivers either the ingredients for these meals, or pre-prepared meals. This might have made the meals more balanced, palatable and convenient. Another thing we did wrong was that we immediately changed from a balanced diet that included meat, fish and diary, to a vegan diet. We probably should have gradually transitioned.

column25: Missed the meat, humans are omnivores, we need a range of foods, found I was hungrier just eating a vegetarian diet and discovered that my digestive system doesn't digest some beans and pulses very well. So now I grow a lot of my own veggies, get eggs from neighbours who keep free ranging hens in their gardens and have reduced the amount of meat in each meal. You asked a question earlier about whether I prioritised taste over animal welfare, the answer was no, but sadly price is a priority over animal welfare and you didn't ask about that.

column21: Completely plant-based/Vegan (eats only plant-based/vegan foods, does not eat any animal products)
column25: in the last 2 years. I had been vegetarian from the age of 13. When I hit menopause I became very unwell and spent 10 years in lots of pain and with many medical problems. It turned out that menopause had made me allergic to lots of main food types. I am now allergic to eggs, dairy, peppers, aubergine, lentils, chilli, paprika, cayenne, tomato, celery, and some nuts. This makes being vegan (through allergies) very difficult as so many vegan and vegetarian very difficult as so many dishes have tomato, pepper and paprika in them. For my health I have started eating a little fish (scallops, salmon, tuna) and iberian ham. The ham is new as in the last couple of months.
column26: if my allergies hadn't occurred I would have happily stayed vegetarian. I started eating some fish because I was craving it and I believe in your body telling you what you need.I started eating Iberian ham as I was holidaying in Spain and it was easier to eat some of that to stay healthy.

column25: They taste like cardboard, especially the vegan cheese. I bought it because it was cheaper but it was just a waste of money as I also bought the real cheese the next day. Vegan sausage is the same. They try to mimic the real thing but do not come close. I think they need to be named differently as I bought the vegan sausage by mistake. I thought it was a regular sausage.
column26: Rename them to exclusive vegan products. They are confusing products when they mimic meat based products.   It is also a matter of economics. What do you propose to those people involved in the meat industry? So that they can have an alternative pay to buy vegan products as their hands are twisted?  It is also a matter of the environment. What are you going to do with the animals increasing in number if you do not kill them?   There's a lot more but these are the few on top of my head.  I think to break the economy of a nation is to become vegan overnight.
